metadata.source: Padma Tendzin: Suhridlekha. Varanasi : Central Institute of High Tibetan Studies (CIHTS), 2002.

children.translated_text: Rich in virtues worthy of natural merit, collected from the words of the <s>Sugata</s> (Buddha),

children.text: śubhamālakṣya kṛtā vai kāścidāryāgītayastvayā ca śravyāḥ // Sl_1 //
children.translated_text: Having observed the auspicious, some noble songs have been composed and should be heard by you.

children.text: dārumayī hyapi pratimā sampūjyate kāpi sugatasya vidvadbhiḥ /
children.translated_text: Even a wooden image of the <s>Sugata</s> is worshiped by the learned,

children.text: tathāmanojñaṃ kāvyaṃ saddharmāśrayācca mamedaṃ na nindyam // Sl_2 //
children.translated_text: Thus, this delightful poetry, being based on the true <s>Dharma</s>, is not to be criticized by me.
I consider the words of the great sage exceedingly sweet, and they should indeed be understood by you,

children.text: ākalpitaṃ tu sudhayā nanvatidhavalaṃ na dṛśyate candrikayā? // Sl_3 //
children.translated_text: But is not the imagined moonlight exceedingly pure, not seen by the moon?
The six recollections, taught by the <s>Jina</s> (Buddha), include <s>Buddha</s>, <s>Dharma</s>, <s>Saṃgha</s>, morality, renunciation, and deities,
Let them be displayed, and with those qualities, they should be individually remembered.
The ten virtuous paths of action, by body, speech, and mind, should always be practiced,
With abstinence from intoxicants and other virtuous livelihoods, one becomes truly content.
Knowing the fleeting and unsubstantial nature of wealth, to the twice-born, mendicants, the poor, and friends,

children.text: dānaṃ deyaṃ vidhinā janmāntareṣu na dānāt paraṃ mitram // Sl_6 //
children.translated_text: Gifts should be given according to the rule; in future births, there is no friend greater than giving.
Unmixed morality should be cultivated by you, unbroken, untransgressed, and untainted,

children.text: carācarapratiṣṭhaṃ tu guṇāśrayaṃ bhūvacca rājate śīlam // Sl_7 //
children.translated_text: Established among the moving and unmoving, based on virtues, morality shines like the earth.
The six perfections are giving, morality, patience, energy, meditation, and wisdom,

children.text: aprameyāḥ saṃvardhya bhavecca bhavasāgarapārago jinendraḥ // Sl_8 //
children.translated_text: By cultivating these immeasurable perfections, one becomes a <s>Jinendra</s> (Lord of Conquerors), crossing the ocean of existence.

children.text: yatra pūjā pitṝṇāṃ kulaṃ tadācāryabrahmabhiḥ samṛddham /
children.translated_text: Where the worship of ancestors is, that family is enriched by teachers and the divine,
Through that worship, fame, and subsequently prosperity, is attained.
Violence, theft, intoxication, sexual misconduct, false speech, dancing, and singing,
Should be abandoned, as well as eating at improper times, garlands, perfumes, and luxurious beds.
By emulating worthy conduct, one should observe the <s>Uposatha</s> with its eight parts,

children.text: labhate hi pumān strī vā suramyakāmāvacarādidevakāyam // Sl_11 //
children.translated_text: For then a man or woman attains the body of a deity in the delightful <s>Kāmāvacara</s> realm.
Jealousy, deceit, hypocrisy, pride, attachment, lethargy, desire, and hatred,
Should be regarded like an enemy, as they arise from family, beauty, youth, learning, and strength.
Non-negligence is the path to immortality, negligence is the path to death, as taught by the sage,
For the growth of virtuous <s>Dharma</s>, non-negligence should always be practiced by you.
Someone previously negligent, like the moon emerging from clouds, then becomes non-negligent,
He shines like <s>Nanda</s>, <s>Aṅgulimāla</s>, <s>Udayana</s>, and <s>Ajātaśatru</s>.

children.text: kṣāntisamaṃ naiva tapastatastvayā na krodhāvasaro deyaḥ /
children.translated_text: There is no asceticism equal to patience, therefore you should not give occasion to anger,
For the state of non-regression is approved by the <s>Buddha</s> through the abandonment of anger.
He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,

children.text: vairairebhiḥ kalahastyajati ya etad vairaṃ sa sukhaṃ śete // Sl_16 //
children.translated_text: One who abandons enmity through these quarrels sleeps happily.

children.text: jale 'vanau pāṣāṇe citramiva cittaṃ tridhā khalu sattvānām /
children.translated_text: Like a drawing on water, land, or stone, the mind is indeed threefold among beings,

children.text: kleśavatāṃ hi prathamo dharmābhilāṣiṇāmantimo jyāyān // Sl_17 //
children.translated_text: The first for those afflicted by defilements, the last is superior for those desiring <s>Dharma</s>.
Speech is threefold as taught by the <s>Jina</s>: sweet, true, and false,

children.text: kramaśo madhuḥ puṣpāśucitulyāścaramā ca pariharttavyaitāsu // Sl_18 //
children.translated_text: Respectively, like honey, flowers, and impurity; the last should be avoided among these.

children.text: caturvidhā vai puruṣāḥ prakāśātprakāśe tamasastamasi punaḥ /
children.translated_text: There are four kinds of people: from light to light, from darkness to darkness again,

children.text: tamaḥ prakāśād gacchati tamasastejasi pudgalo varaḥ prathamaḥ // Sl_19 //
children.translated_text: From darkness to light, and from light to darkness; the best is the one who goes from darkness to light.
Among people, like a ripe mango fruit, unripe, ripe, and like unripe in ripe,

children.text: apakve 'pakvaṃ tathā pakve pakvamiva bhāti cāturvidhyam // Sl_20 //
children.translated_text: In the unripe, unripe, and in the ripe, like ripe; such is the fourfold nature.

children.text: paradārānna tu paśyed dṛṣṭe ca jñeyā avasthānurūpyeṇa /
children.translated_text: One should not look at others' spouses, and if seen, they should be regarded according to their status,
Like a daughter, mother, or sister; even in attachment, one should think of them as impure.
One should protect the restless mind, like one's son, wealth, or life,
The mind should be avoided like an enemy, snake, poison, weapon, or fire from desire.
<s>Kāma</s> (desire) is said to be the cause of misfortune, like the fruit of a <s>kimpāka</s>, by the <s>Jinendra</s>,

children.text: pāśaistasya hi baddho bhavacārake lokaḥ sa prahātavyaḥ // Sl_23 //
children.translated_text: The world is bound by its snares in the prison of existence, and it should be abandoned.

children.text: calādhruvāṇi ṣaḍakṣāṇi jayanti samare vā śatrūnapi caike /
children.translated_text: The unstable and impermanent six senses conquer in battle or even enemies,

children.text: tayośca sudhiyaḥ prathamaṃ varamindriyavijetāraṃ ca manyante // Sl_24 //
children.translated_text: And among them, the wise consider the first one as the best, the conqueror of the senses.
Indeed, the body of a young woman is foul, having nine impure openings, like an impure vessel,

children.text: carmāvṛtaduṣpūraṃ bhūṣitamapi bhūṣaṇaiḥ pṛthag draṣṭavyam // Sl_25 //
children.translated_text: Covered with skin, hard to fill, even if adorned with ornaments, it should be seen separately.

children.text: kṛmipīḍito hi kuṣṭhī sukhalipsayā ca yathā vahnimāśrayate /
children.translated_text: As a leper afflicted by worms seeks fire for the desire of happiness,

children.text: pīḍā na yāti śāntiṃ tathaiva hi kāmāsaktirapi boddhavyā // Sl_26 //
children.translated_text: The pain does not find peace; similarly, attachment to desire should be understood.

children.text: paramārthaṃ prativettuṃ sarvabhāveṣu savidhi manasi nidhāyaiva /
children.translated_text: To truly comprehend, placing with method in the mind all states,

children.text: sa ca khalu bhāvayitavyo na hi tattulyo 'paro guṇayuto dharmaḥ // Sl_27 //
children.translated_text: And indeed, it should be meditated upon, for no other virtue-laden <s>dharma</s> is equal to it.

children.text: sukulīno 'pi na pūjyo jñānaśīlavimukho śrutirūpavān pumān /
children.translated_text: Even if well-born, not worthy of honor is a man devoid of knowledge and character, though possessing learning and beauty,
One endowed with these two virtues is honored, even if lacking in other qualities, always.
In the eight worldly conditions, the wise should engage the mind with equanimity,
In gain and loss, fame and infamy, praise and blame, pleasure and pain, which are not to be mourned.
By you, towards <s>Brahmins</s>, mendicants, deities, guests, mother, father, family, and queen,

children.text: pāpaṃ nācaraṇiyaṃ yataḥ katamo 'pi na narakaphalasya bhāgī // Sl_30 //
children.translated_text: Sin should not be committed, for not any one of them is a partaker of hellish fruit.

children.text: na ca kṛntati pāpakarma tatkṣaṇamastrapātavat kamapi pāpinam /
children.translated_text: And sinful action does not cut off anyone at that moment like a weapon's blow,

children.text: mṛtyorhi samaye kintu tatkarmaṇaḥ phalamabhimukhībhavatyeva // Sl_31 //
children.translated_text: But at the time of death, the fruit of that action indeed confronts.
Seven treasures are stated: faith, morality, renunciation, purity, learning, wisdom,

children.text: apatrapā hrī muninā mudhaivāparadhanāni hi sādhāraṇāni // Sl_32 //
children.translated_text: Shame, modesty; by the sage, other wealths are indeed common and worthless.
Gambling, shows of curiosity, laziness, association with bad friends, and liquor,

children.text: niśāviharaṇaṃ ṣaḍime tyājyā durgatidā yaśovināśakāśca // Sl_33 //
children.translated_text: Night wandering, these six should be abandoned, as they lead to ruin and destroy fame.
By the ruler of men and gods, contentment is declared the foremost of all wealths,

children.text: santoṣo 'nuṣṭheyaḥ dhanaṃ vinaiva sa dhanikaḥ sati santoṣe // Sl_34 //
children.translated_text: Contentment should be practiced, for without wealth, one is wealthy if there is contentment.

children.text: yathā samṛddhāḥ puruṣā duḥkhino bhavanti naiva tathālpecchukāḥ /
children.translated_text: As prosperous men become unhappy, not so those with few desires,

children.text: yāvatyaḥ santi phaṇā ārya, duḥkhakarāḥ, nāgasya tāvatyaḥ // Sl_35 //
children.translated_text: Just as there are as many hoods, noble one, causing pain, of the serpent.

children.text: patnī tyājyā trividhā prakṛtyā ripusambaddhā svaghātikeva /
children.translated_text: A wife should be abandoned of three kinds by nature: connected with enemies, like a self-destroyer,
One who dishonors her husband, promiscuous, inclined to petty theft, like a thief.
Like a sister, agreeable, like a friend, cherished in the heart, should be served,
Helpful like a mother, venerable, like a servant obeying orders, like a goddess.
Abandoning attachment and aversion, food should be taken as medicine,

children.text: kāyasthityai nitarāṃ na ca saundaryagarvamānārthaṃ sevyam // Sl_38 //
children.translated_text: For the maintenance of the body, not excessively, nor for pride in beauty or arrogance.

children.text: dinamakhilaṃ śubhakārye yāpayed rātrerādyantau yāmau ca /
children.translated_text: The entire day should be spent in auspicious activities, and the first and last watches of the night,

children.text: dhīman, madhye yāme śayīta yato hi na bhaved viphalā nidrā // Sl_39 //
children.translated_text: Wise one, in the middle watch, one should sleep, for sleep would not be fruitless.
Friendliness, compassion, equanimity, and joy should always be properly cultivated,
In the unattained supreme state, surely there is attainment of happiness in <s>Brahmaloka</s>.

children.text: kāmān prītivicārau sukhañca duḥkhañca vihāya caturbhireva /
children.translated_text: Desires, thoughts of love, pleasure, and pain, abandoning all four,
Through meditations, they become partakers of the luminous, auspicious, complete and great fruit of <s>Brahma</s>.
Both skillful and unskillful actions, with constant engagement and opposing qualities,
Arise from five, hence effort should be made in virtuous conduct.
Just as a small amount of salty water changes the taste of a little water, not the <s>Ganges</s>,

children.text: pāpaṃ tathaiva cālpaṃ nāśayatyalpakuśalaṃ na pūrṇakuśalam // Sl_43 //
children.translated_text: Similarly, a little sin destroys a little virtue, not complete virtue.

children.text: auddhatyaṃ kaukṛtyaṃ vyāpādaḥ styānamiddhe ca kāmecchā /
children.translated_text: Restlessness, remorse, ill-will, sloth, torpor, and desire,
And doubt; these five are known as the thieves of virtuous wealth.
The five superior <s>dharmas</s> are faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom,

children.text: balendriyāṇi cāgryāṇi kathyante yatanīyameteṣu tasmād // Sl_45 //
children.translated_text: And the foremost powers and faculties, hence effort should be made in these.
All, devoted to actions, like disease, old age, death, and separation from loved ones,

children.text: punaḥ punastu cintayā pratipakṣeṇaivaṃ prahīyate mānaḥ // Sl_46 //
children.translated_text: Again and again, by thinking in opposition, thus pride is diminished.
If one desires heaven and liberation, right view should indeed be cultivated,

children.text: kṛtāni mithyādṛṣṭyā puruṣaiḥ sucaritānyapi viṣamavipākāni // Sl_47 //
children.translated_text: For actions done with wrong view, even if good, ripen with adverse results.
The non-self, impure, sorrowful, and impermanent individual must be rightly understood
Those devoid of mindfulness perish through four perversions

children.text: uktaṃ rūpaṃ nātmā rūpavāṃśca nātmā rūpe naivātmā /
children.translated_text: It is said that form is not the self, nor is the self possessed of form, nor is the self in form

children.text: na cātmanyasti rūpaṃ śūnyamevaṃ skandhacatuṣkamapi jñeyam // Sl_49 //
children.translated_text: Nor is form in the self; thus, the four aggregates are to be known as empty

children.text: skandhā na hi jāyante yadṛcchayā na prakṛtīśvarakālebhyaḥ /
children.translated_text: The aggregates do not arise by chance, nor from <s>Prakṛti<s/> (primordial nature), <s>Īśvara<s/> (God), or time

children.text: nāhetoḥ svabhāvato jñeyā ajñānena tṛṣṇayā jātāḥ // Sl_50 //
children.translated_text: Nor from a cause, nor by nature; they are born from ignorance and craving

children.text: kālaḥ pacati bhūtāni kālaḥ saṃharate prajāḥ /
children.translated_text: <s>Kāla<s/> (time) cooks all beings, <s>Kāla<s/> withdraws the creatures

children.text: kālaḥ supteṣu jāgarti kālo hi duratikramaḥ //
children.translated_text: <s>Kāla<s/> remains awake among the sleeping; indeed, <s>Kāla<s/> is insurmountable
False view in the self, clinging to rules and vows, and doubt
Are to be understood as the three fetters obstructing the gates of liberation

children.text: ātmāpekṣo mokṣaḥ parasmānna labhyate kimapi sāhāyyam /
children.translated_text: Liberation depends on the self, no assistance is obtained from another
One should practice the four noble truths with conduct, study, and reflection
The three trainings of higher morality, mind, and wisdom should always be cultivated
Within these are included one hundred and fifty rules of training
O king, the mindfulness related to the body is said by the Buddha to be the sole path
One should protect this with effort, for from the destruction of mindfulness comes the destruction of all <s>dharmas<s/>
Life is full of many troubles, like a bubble formed by the wind on water, and impermanent
It is a wonder that this moment of wakefulness exists amidst breaths and sleep
The body is of a nature that decays, decomposes, putrefies, dries, is insubstantial, and impure

children.text: rajaḥsadharmī cānte sadā viyogaśīlo naśvaro jñeyaḥ // Sl_56 //
children.translated_text: Like dust in nature, it is always separable and perishable
The earth, <s>Meru<s/>, and oceans, with the seven suns' flames, will not remain

children.text: dhūlimātraṃ hi mūrtāḥ kā kathā durbalavapuṣāṃ mānavānām // Sl_57 //
children.translated_text: They will become mere dust; what to say of the frail bodies of men
Thus, everything is impermanent, non-self, without refuge, without protector, without abode
Like a banana tree, O king, remove the mind from the essence-less <s>saṃsāra<s/>
Human birth is like placing a tortoise's neck through a yoke in the great ocean
Difficult to obtain like lower births, make it fruitful by practicing the true <s>Dharma<s/>, O king
Some fill a jewel-adorned golden vessel with excrement

children.text: tato 'pyasāvatimūḍho yaśca nṛjanma labdhvāpi pāpamācarati // Sl_60 //
children.translated_text: More foolish than that is he who, having obtained human birth, commits sin
Dwelling in a suitable place, relying on good people, and making auspicious resolutions

children.text: svakīyapūrvakuśalaṃ hyetaccakracatuṣkaṃ hi vidyate tvayi // Sl_61 //
children.translated_text: These are the four wheels of one's previous merit that exist in you
Service to noble friends is taught by the sage for the fulfillment of celibacy

children.text: sevyaḥ sadā supuruṣaḥ śamaḥ prāpto yato jinamapekṣya bahubhiḥ // Sl_62 //
children.translated_text: Always serve a virtuous person, peace is attained by many through reliance on the <s>Jina<s/>
Those with false views are born in hell, among pretas, and animals

children.text: mleccho jaḍaśca sattvo yo hyutpanno buddhavirahite // Sl_63 //
children.translated_text: The being born in a land without the Buddha is a barbarian and dull
These faults are in one born in a long-lived divine family, having eight inopportune moments

children.text: ebhī rahito bhūtvā kṣaṇaṃ labdhvā janmanivṛttau prayateta // Sl_64 //
children.translated_text: Being free from these, having obtained a moment, one should strive for cessation of rebirth
<s>Saṃsāra<s/> brings sufferings such as the loss of the desired, disease, death, and old age

children.text: virajya tataḥ śṛṇu tāvad doṣānetasyāvagacchan naradeva // Sl_65 //
children.translated_text: Renouncing it, listen then, realizing these faults, O king of men

children.text: mitratvena ca śatruḥ putratvena pitāmbā ca bhāryātvena /
children.translated_text: As a friend, an enemy; as a son, a father; and as a wife, a mother

children.text: parivartyotpadyante tasmānna niyataṃ kimapīha saṃsāre // Sl_66 //
children.translated_text: Arise through transformation; therefore, nothing is certain here in <s>saṃsāra<s/>
More than the water in the four oceans is the mother's milk drunk by beings

children.text: pṛthagjanānanusṛtya hi punastato 'pyadhikañca pāsyanti lokāḥ // Sl_67 //
children.translated_text: Following different births, beings will again drink even more than that
The pile of one's bones would grow as high as <s>Meru<s/> and even higher

children.text: bhūmimṛdā badarāṇāṃ gulikābhirna gaṇanā sambhavāmbānām // Sl_68 //
children.translated_text: With the earth's soil and berries, the counting of waters is not possible

children.text: lokapūjyo 'pi śakraḥ patati ca punaḥ karmavaśāddhi saṃsāre /
children.translated_text: Even <s>Śakra<s/>, worshipped by the world, falls again due to karma in <s>saṃsāra<s/>

children.text: tadvacca cakravartī rājāpi punarbhavati hi dāso loke // Sl_69 //
children.translated_text: Likewise, the <s>cakravartī<s/> king also becomes a servant again in the world
Having long enjoyed the pleasure of the touch of celestial maidens' breasts in heaven
One experiences unbearable suffering in hell with crushing, cutting, and breaking instruments
sukhade sumeruśikhare ciramanubhavaṃścaraṃścaraṇasparśasukham /

children.text: cañcalakukkulakuṇapairgāḍhaṃ duḥkhaṃ cintayet sadā manasā // Sl_71 //
children.translated_text: One should always contemplate deeply with the mind on the intense suffering caused by restless worms and corpses

children.text: devāṅganāsevite nandane ramye copavane ca vihṛtya /
children.translated_text: Having enjoyed in the beautiful grove of <s>Nandana</s> attended by celestial maidens,
In the forest of sword-like leaves, their hands, feet, ears, and noses are cut off
In the <s>Mandākinī</s> adorned with golden lotuses and beautiful celestial maidens,

children.text: snātvā punaśca narake kṣāroṣṇodakavaitaraṇyāṃ hi patanti // Sl_73 //
children.translated_text: After bathing, they again fall into the hell of <s>Vaitaraṇī</s> with hot and saline water
In the realms of the gods, there is pleasure from desire, and in the realms of <s>Brahma</s>, pleasure from detachment from desire,

children.text: prāpyāvīcau satataṃ labhyate 'gnerindhanībhūya ca duḥkham // Sl_74 //
children.translated_text: Having attained these, constant suffering is obtained by becoming fuel for fire in <s>Avīci</s>

children.text: padamavāpya suryendvoḥ svakāyaprabhayā pradīpya hi saṃsāram /
children.translated_text: Having attained the position of <s>Sūrya</s> and <s>Indu</s>, illuminating the world with the light of their own bodies,

children.text: tamasi ca ghane praviṣṭaḥ prasāritamapi ca svīyakaraṃ na paśyati // Sl_75 //
children.translated_text: Entering into dense darkness, one does not see even their own outstretched hand
Thus knowing death, one should grasp the light of the threefold meritorious lamp,
Otherwise, one must enter the crushing darkness which is not dispelled by <s>Ravi</s> and <s>Indu</s>
Beings attached to evil conduct, in the tortures of the cords of life,

children.text: rauravāvīcyādau hi saṃghāte cāpi narake sadā duḥkham // Sl_77 //
children.translated_text: In <s>Raurava</s>, <s>Avīci</s>, and other such hells, there is always suffering

children.text: niṣpīḍyante tilavat kecanānye cūrṇavat peṣyante ca /
children.translated_text: Some are squeezed like sesame seeds, others are ground like powder,

children.text: chidyante śāṇenānye dīryante tathā tīkṣṇaparaśunāpi // Sl_78 //
children.translated_text: Some are cut with a whetstone, others are split with a sharp axe
Into the mouths of others, molten iron is poured in the same way,

children.text: āropyante kecana sakaṇṭake taptāyase sadā śūle // Sl_79 //
children.translated_text: Some are impaled on hot iron stakes with thorns
Some are torn apart by cruel dogs with iron teeth, roaring,

children.text: utthāya karau vivaśā luñcyante tīkṣṇanakhatuṇḍaiśca kākaiḥ // Sl_80 //
children.translated_text: Rising up, their hands are helplessly plucked by crows with sharp nails and beaks
Some, due to the touch of worms, and the falling of black flies on their flesh,

children.text: vṛddhaṃ vraṇantvasahyaṃ bhakṣyamāṇaṃ rudanti cākulā bhūmyām // Sl_81 //
children.translated_text: Being devoured, cry out in distress on the ground, unable to bear the unbearable wounds

children.text: dahyante 'gnikuṇḍeṣu tena tadānanāni ca bhavanti vivṛtāni /
children.translated_text: They are burned in fire pits, and then their mouths become wide open,
They are cooked in iron cauldrons like rice grains, with heads downwards

children.text: śvāsāvarodhasamaye pāpaḥ kālaṃkṛte ca narakaṃ prayāti /
children.translated_text: At the time of breath obstruction, the sinner goes to hell,

children.text: śrutvāpi narakaduḥkhaṃ sahasraśo vajrasvabhāvātra bibheti // Sl_83 //
children.translated_text: Even hearing of the thousandfold suffering of hell, one fears like a diamond

children.text: śrutvā dṛṣṭvā smṛtvā paṭhitvā cāpi citrāṅkanaṃ narakasya /
children.translated_text: Having heard, seen, remembered, and also read the depiction of hell,

children.text: ākṛtirapi bhayajanikā kā kathā tadasahyavipākānubhavasya // Sl_84 //
children.translated_text: Even its form is fear-inducing; what to say of experiencing its unbearable consequences

children.text: yathā samastasukhānāṃ tṛṣṇākṣaya eva sarvottamaṃ sukhamiti /
children.translated_text: Just as the cessation of desire is considered the highest happiness among all pleasures,
So among all sufferings, the suffering of <s>Avīci</s> hell is most unbearable

children.text: ihaikasmiṃśca divase, triśataśūlaghātād bhavati ca yad duḥkham /
children.translated_text: Here, in one day, the suffering that arises from being pierced by three hundred spears,

children.text: nārakīyaduḥkhasya hi tatrāpnoti samatāṃ na laghukalāṃ cāpi // Sl_86 //
children.translated_text: Does not equal even a fraction of the suffering of hell
Even while experiencing extremely harsh sufferings for a period of ten million years,

children.text: yāvattānyakuśalāni na kṣīṇāni tāvatra jīvanānmuktiḥ // Sl_87 //
children.translated_text: Until those unwholesome actions are exhausted, there is no liberation from life
The seeds of undesirable fruits are indeed the misdeeds of body, speech, and mind,

children.text: bhavataivaṃ yatanīyaṃ śaktyā yena tadaṇumātraṃ na śiṣyeta // Sl_88 //
children.translated_text: Thus, one should strive with effort so that not even an atom of it remains

children.text: tiryagyoniṣu nānā duḥkhāni bhavanti ca badhabandhanādīni /
children.translated_text: In animal realms, various sufferings occur, including capture and bondage,
They devour each other, devoid of the root of peace and virtuous actions
Some creatures are indeed killed for the sake of wool, bones, flesh, and skin,

children.text: yojyante khalu vivaśā anye padamuṣṭikaśāṅkuśaiḥ paśavaśca // Sl_90 //
children.translated_text: Others, helpless, are yoked with foot, fist, and hook

children.text: pretayonau na kṣayaṃ yātīṣṭālābhajanitā duḥkhadhārā ca /
children.translated_text: In the <s>Preta</s> realm, the stream of suffering caused by the absence of desired gains does not diminish,
One obtains unbearable suffering caused by cold, heat, hunger, thirst, fatigue, and fear
Some have mouths like a needle's eye, but their stomachs are as vast as a mountain,

children.text: tacca pīḍitaṃ kṣudhayā kṣiptamaśuci vastu na pratikārakṣamam // Sl_92 //
children.translated_text: And that is tormented by hunger, thrown with impure objects, unable to remedy
Some <s>Pretas</s> are naked, with bodies like dry palm tops, mere skin and bones,
At night, they emit fire from their mouths, consuming falling hot sand

children.text: nimnakoṭikaiḥ kaiścit pūyaraktādyaśucīni na ca labhyante /
children.translated_text: Some, with low status, do not obtain even impure things like pus and blood,
Seizing upon another's face, they eat the flowing saliva and other discharges

children.text: candro grīṣme taptaḥ śaitye śīto bhānuśca hyetebhyaḥ /
children.translated_text: The moon is hot in summer, and the sun is cold in winter for them

children.text: teṣāṃ dṛṣṭi pātācca niṣphalāstaravo nadyaśca śuṣyante // Sl_95 //
children.translated_text: From their gaze, the trees become fruitless and the rivers dry up
They are always partakers of sorrow, firmly bound by the fetters of evil deeds,

children.text: na ca mriyante kecit pañca vā daśa sahasravarṣāṇi sattvāḥ // Sl_96 //
children.translated_text: and some beings do not die for five or even ten thousand years
And what the <s>pretas</s> (spirits) obtain is a taste of various kinds of sorrows, in such a manner
Joy here is said by the Buddha to be in miserliness, envy, and ignobility
In heaven, there is excessive happiness, yet greater sorrow from falling from there, certainly

children.text: evaṃ vicintya tajjñaiḥ kṣaratsukhāya na tṛṣṇā kāryā svarge // Sl_98 //
children.translated_text: Thus considering, the wise should not desire the perishable happiness of heaven

children.text: vaivarṇyaṃ dehasya svāsane na ratirmlāyate 'pi mālā ca /
children.translated_text: Discoloration of the body, in one's seat, there is no pleasure, even the garland withers

children.text: vasaneṣvapi daurgandhyaṃ svedaścāpūrvo niryāti dehāttu // Sl_99 //
children.translated_text: In clothes too, there is foul smell, and unprecedented sweat emerges from the body
Indeed, there are five signs of death among the gods dwelling in heaven
Similar to those of humans on earth, and also with the signs of death
When fallen from the gods, if not even a small measure of merit remains
Then one must helplessly wander among animals, <s>pretas</s>, and hells
Mental suffering may arise, envying the divine majesty, even among gods

children.text: na kurvanti dhīmanto janmāvaraṇācca te satyadarśanāni // Sl_102 //
children.translated_text: The wise do not act due to the veil of birth, and their visions of truth
In this <s>saṃsāra</s>, thus among gods, hells, <s>pretas</s>, and animal births

children.text: janmagrahaṇamayuktaṃ bahubādhaṃ janma tatreti vijñeyam // Sl_103 //
children.translated_text: Taking birth is inappropriate and troublesome, birth there is to be understood

children.text: jvalite śirasi ca vasane tannivṛttyupāyamupekṣya tvaritameva /
children.translated_text: When the head and clothes are burning, neglecting the means of cessation, hastily
One should strive for non-rebirth, since there is no greater purpose than that
With <s>śīla</s>, <s>samādhi</s>, and <s>jñāna</s>, without earth, water, fire, air, and sun
One attains the undying, deathless, inexhaustible, peaceful, controlled, pure <s>nirvāṇa</s>
The seven are relaxation, energy, joy, investigation of <s>dharma</s>, mindfulness, concentration, equanimity
These are the factors of enlightenment, the accumulation of merit for attaining <s>nirvāṇa</s>

children.text: prajñābhāve dhyānaṃ dhyānābhāve 'pi na jāyate sā prajñā /
children.translated_text: In the absence of wisdom, meditation does not arise; in the absence of meditation, wisdom does not arise

children.text: yatrobhe vidyete jñeyastasya bhavasāgaro goṣpadavat // Sl_107 //
children.translated_text: Where both are present, his ocean of existence is to be known as the size of a cow's hoofprint
Those who are the indeterminate <s>dharma</s>s taught by the friend of the sun, the fourteen

children.text: loke na cintanīyā yato tairnāpnoti cittameva śāntim // Sl_108 //
children.translated_text: In the world, they should not be contemplated, since by them the mind does not obtain peace

children.text: evaṃ proktaṃ munināvidyayā karma karmaṇā ca vijñānam /
children.translated_text: Thus it is said by the sage, by ignorance there is action, by action there is knowledge

children.text: tasmācca nāmarūpaṃ tataḥ ṣaḍāyatanāni tataḥ sparśā vai // Sl_109 //
children.translated_text: From that, <s>nāma-rūpa</s> (name and form), then the six senses, then indeed contact

children.text: tata utpannā vittirvedanāśrayeṇa jāyate khalu tṛṣṇā /
children.translated_text: Then arises sensation, and from sensation, craving is indeed born

children.text: tasyāścopādānaṃ tato bhavo 'pi bhavācca jāyate jātiḥ // Sl_110 //
children.translated_text: And from that craving, attachment, then existence, and from existence, birth is born
When birth exists, there are sorrows, diseases, old age, desires, non-obtainment, fear, and death

children.text: duḥkhaskandho vipulaḥ sati jātiniṣedhe niṣiddhānīmāni // Sl_111 //
children.translated_text: The heap of sorrow is vast; with the negation of birth, these are negated
Profound, priceless treasure, dear is the dependent origination of the Buddha's words

children.text: samyagimaṃ yaḥ paśyati sa ca paśyati tattvadarśinaṃ buddhameva // Sl_112 //
children.translated_text: Who sees this rightly, he sees the truth-seeing Buddha himself
For peace, to be cultivated are right view, intention, speech, action, livelihood, and mindfulness
Concentration, effort, and these are the noble eightfold path with beauty

children.text: jātiriyaṃ duḥkhameva tṛṣṇā ca tasya samudayo mahān jñeyaḥ /
children.translated_text: This birth is indeed suffering, and craving is to be known as its great arising
Cessation is <s>nirvāṇa</s>, and for its attainment is this eightfold path
Effort should always be made for the realization of the four noble truths, thus

children.text: kroḍe śriyaśca yeṣāṃ gṛhasthāstaranti kleśanadīṃ jñānāt // Sl_115 //
children.translated_text: In the embrace of whose wealth, householders cross the river of afflictions through knowledge
Those who have seen the noble truths do not arise like sprouts from the earth

children.text: nāvataranti ca gaganāt te 'pi pṛthagjanāḥ kleśavaśā hi pūrvam // Sl_116 //
children.translated_text: Nor do they descend from the sky, they too were ordinary people, previously under the sway of afflictions

children.text: cittaṃ hi dharmamūlaṃ bhagavatoktamatastadapi sādhu damayecca /
children.translated_text: The mind is indeed the root of <s>dharma</s>, as said by the Blessed One, therefore it should also be well controlled

children.text: bho nirbhaya, kiṃ bahunā kathanena yato 'yameva hitopadeśaḥ // Sl_117 //
children.translated_text: Oh fearless one, why say much, since this is indeed the beneficial advice
What I have instructed, even with efforts, is difficult to accomplish by the monks

children.text: caryāguṇān sevasva śikṣāmācara jīvanaṃ ca kuru sārtham // Sl_118 //
children.translated_text: Practice the virtues of conduct, engage in training, and make life meaningful

children.text: sarveṣāṃ kuśalāni tu sarvārthamanumodya svacaryātrayīṃ ca /
children.translated_text: All meritorious deeds, indeed, for the sake of all, approve and follow the threefold conduct

children.text: buddhatvāya pariṇāmya tatastadanena puṇyarāśinā bhavatā // Sl_119 //
children.translated_text: Transforming towards enlightenment, then by this accumulation of merit you become,
In births beyond measure, having mastered the gods, humans, and <s>yogins</s>,
The suffering, who are to be assisted without companions, through the conduct of <s>Avalokiteśvara</s>
Having attained the final existence, and abandoning disease, old age, attachment, and aversion,
In the <s>Buddha-kṣetra</s> become like the Blessed <s>Amitābha</s>, a lord of infinite life
Through wisdom and conduct, manifesting pure fame on earth, in the sky, and in heaven,

children.text: loke prasārya śamayan narān yuvatisukharatadevāṃśca bhūmau // Sl_122 //
children.translated_text: Spreading peace in the world, calming humans, young women, and joyful gods on earth
For beings afflicted by afflictions, destroying the fear of birth and death, known as <s>Jinendra</s>,
Attain the transcendental, undefiled, peaceful, fearless, and imperishable state

body.translated_text: Thus the letter to a friend is completed
